rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Aydin is a funny, interesting, and very intelligent man. His class seems hard at first but he is a very easy grader (I got 100 on every paper) because he cares more about you showing you learned something than actual grading. He assigns a lot of reading but you can get through it by skimming. There were no tests or quizzes.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I loved Bullard. She was extremely kind and helpful. The class was interesting and she made it very enjoyable.

Extremely knowledgeable about the subject, very interesting, and if you are interested in the Renaissance, then you will love this class.  However, she expects a lot out of the students, and expects you to thoroughly understand the material.  Exams are essay format and graded critically and are VERY difficult unless you study intensively.
The lectures teach random ideas and thoughts and the tests are graded extremely tough.  Don't go into class thinking an "A" is automatic--it seriously has to be earned.

Knows her stuff, is extremely amiable, in a grandma-ish way (she also looks like a grandma). This makes her relatively boring though and tests are blue book and graded rather intensively. Wouldn't recommend, but not a bad choice.
The lectures are really boring... Made me feel sleepy alot.. Exams are okay but long..

Honors 'seminar' on the history of Economics: Bullard is excited about the course material, eager to motivate discussion, and very fair with writing and grading exams. Her required mini-journal/synopses are helpful as well in absorbing the material. Three hours of class in one sitting was rough though, be warned.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Absolutely wonderful professor. Expert in his field. I took it over the summer, so no TA's. Midterm was 40%, final was 60%. Very strict grader. For the text, read HIS books (that he wrote)..... you'll learn much more than the assigned readings.

I had Professor Barney for a Civil War course at Trenton State College (now The College of New Jersey)in 1975.  Almost 40 years and 3 master degrees later, Professor Barney still ranks as one of my best professors ever.  (And I am happy to report that my youngest daughter will be a freshman this year at Gettysburg College! What irony!!).

He knows the Civil War inside and out, which I thought would be good, but the entire class was just horrendously boring blow-by-blow details of every single battle, troop movement, shot fired, etc. Definitely taught as a PWAD and not a HIST class. Also does not touch on Reconstruction at all, so no clue why that's in the course title.
knowledgeable but terrible teacher. grades papers like hes pissed off and doesnt give advice on them. avoid this guy

Fantastic Professor.  I enjoyed his lectures, and I actually thought that he was very entertaining.  The two midterms are graded by TA's, so if you have a good one like I did, it is possible to succeed.  However, the final is graded by Barney, and he is a Stickler.  You are given the material for the test prior to the test, so STUDY IT ALL!

Dr. Barney rocks! He knows everything about American history and includes really insteresting details in his lectures. Two of the three tests are graded by TAs, so prepare for the final really well because he grades very harshly. This is the most interesting class I've taken at Carolina!

Engaging speaking who loves what he teaches.  Mid-term and Final only -- but very difficult if you are not prepared, and it is critical that you do well on the exams as there is nothing else to off-set your grade.  Makes himself available if you have questions or need help.  Great class!

An interesting and engaging lecturer. You can really tell he loves what he's teaching and he passes it on to his students. The tests are hard, but if you study enough and pay attention in recitations you'll do well. NOT impossible to get an A.

Dr. Barney looks like he stepped right out of the Civil War and his personality fits what he teaches. He can be very interesting at times and very dull at other times. I took his class on the Civil War and he wrote the book which matched his lectures almost word for word. It is an easy class if you are happy with a B it is difficult to get an A.

Class is a challenge, but he is a good professor. Lectures well, I found the subject matter engaging. 1 essay and 2 big tests make up all of your grade, can really be sink or swim. He will give you review guides beforehand, go to the review session held by the TA and study hard. He grades all his finals, TA splits work otherwise.

Barney was a great lecturer, IMO. Much of his grading is done by his TAs so it depends on them. He grades the final and it's hard to determine what he expects because that's all he grades. He gives you test questions in advance and the material is almost all covered in lecture.
Very strict on grading, much of which is done by TA's. Mine was very tough, making taking this class a regret.

This older man is a wealth of information, and has written countless history texts, read the book he assigns (and wrote himself)..BUT his lectures lend themselves to dozing off. Three essay style tests- its IMPOSSIBLE to earn an A.
He knows his stuff, and lectures from start to finish. But he's a stickler, and his TAs determine the grades.

He knew the material, but his TAs give B.S. grades and the class is ridiculously boring. If you take this class, you don't need to go to class, but you do need to be able to write well and a lot on your tests.

BARNEY RULES! I had never learned so much History in my whole life. Mostly political view. He lectures every second of the class and so keep up with the notes and GO TO CLASS. 3 noncumulative essay tests in the semester. Text book will save your life. I highly recommend any of his classes.
Very interesting class, you learn a lot, about things you never have thought about.  But, the tests require a lot of preparation, and it's hard to get an A, well, almost impossible.
A Very dedicated teacher, knows his stuff, i.e. all the books, all the subjects concerning Civil War and Reconstruction.
makes history seem more like a story rather than facts we have to learn... good lecturer
Take good notes and you will do fine.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Leloudis is a great guy with a deep passion and knowledge for NC history. He''s been at the University for a good while works with the Southern Historical Collection and the Honors College. He  his TAs are more than willing to help with your papers to get you where you need to be to get a good grade. Study for the MC portion of the exams.

367 was one of the best classes I've taken at UNC. It's not hard and it's really interesting. There are three noncumulative take home essays (one is the final) and a short fill-in-the-blank portion for each.

A good professor but tends to ramble. Keeps the class within a black-white focus, so that I wonder what happened to all of the Indians, Hispanics, and Asians in our state. So in that, he is biased. He also gives an aura of not being accepting to criticism... has other duties at the University so is not available after class much of the time.

He's a great professor. I agree his lectures are very well structured and interesting. He definitely knows his stuff.  If you do the work it will show. Just keep up with readings and go to class (its mandatory) and you'll do fine!

A fine teacher, well-structured lessons with themes he ties well. Interesting if you live in NC. Only frustrating aspect is his attendance policy (daily sign-in), claims he will bump grades in light of good attendance. I needed a fraction of a point and had perfect attendance, even went to office hrs. Wouldn't give me the fraction for an bump.
Not sure i'd say he's the best professor...he's ok. biased though.
The best teacher at UNC.  If you don't take his class, you're missing out.
No Comments
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Waterhouse is a great lecturer who really knows about American political and business history.  I took HIST 372 (politics and society since the New Deal) and it was one of the best history courses I've taken at Carolina.

A very hands on class. The first part of the semester includes a lot of reading, but the second half is all group work. He is very flexible with the schedule and will give you extra time. Aways cheerful and very knowledgable in the subject.

Lectures are entertaining and upbeat. Gives life to American History and makes it much more interesting and easy to understand. Assignments are in essay form. Midterms and exams are in essay form. Great class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I got a B in the class. I thought this professor was a really good teacher, but I felt she was teaching the wrong things. For example, we totally skipped WW1 and WW2. I worked hard and read maybe 85% of the readings.

I didn't enjoy this class whatsoever. The lectures are so boring and Professor Jackson expects you to memorize everything shes ever said. The tests are all essays, she grades harshly, and they are never clear. I was left confused after every lecture. Along with this, she is not helpful if you talk to her outside of class either. Would not recommend

Jerma Jackson is the worst professor I have ever had at UNC. She gives you an insane amount of info in lecture, and expects you to remember it all in insane detail. There are also very lengthy readings before every class, which you're practically expected to memorize. The test are 100% essay based. If you care about your GPA, don't take her class.

Her powerpoint are not helpful at all and the textbook is just a bunch of different readings. She basically just talks the entire class and so its really hard to write down all of the important things because if you miss them when she's talking there's nowhere else to find them. Super boring wouldn't take her as a prof.
Really enjoyed lecture. Super engaging, really kind. Great history class.

If you value your time and want to even marginally enjoy your semester do not take anything with her.Her lectures have little substance and she will literally spend the entire time reading powerpoints to you and "analyzing pictures" by making obvious statements about them.Also,she has an annoying voice and talks to people like they are children.

Professor Jackson is a great lecturer. Her class is one of my favorites just because it's interesting! Your TA determines your grade, but Jackson creates the prompts for the writing assignments that will be due every other week. Certainly not an 'easy A' class. She often requires you to stay past the scheduled class time so prepare for that.

Don't expect a good grade, but if you're one of those rare people who come to college looking to be challenged and better yourself, take her class! She has real wisdom and, like any teacher worth learning from, she makes you work for it. If you leave her class angry at anyone but yourself you're doing it wrong.

Literally the worst teacher I've ever had. Rude, mean and moody. Often demands class stay past time. Supposed to be an American History class, basically AfAm hist class without the diversity credit. Asks for "significance" on tests, but grades by seeking specific answers instead of seeing what you know like most history classes. Horrible experience

Dr. Jackson is great! She pushes you hard, and makes you defend your point of view, but in her class I became a much stronger writer and critical thinker. Classes like this with professors like her are what college is all about!

Horrible professor. FYS's are supposed to be easier than other classes. Instead, she assigned 2 2-page papers a week, acted like this was the only class her students were taking, and took pride in giving out only 1 A for each assignment. She needs to get over herself.

She is an interesting professor, and she really knows her stuff.  What is really frustrating, however, is the way she grades.  I took her first year seminar expecting it to be an easy A, as all FYSs really should be, but instead I'll be lucky to make a B.

Jackson is an amazing professor. She really knows the information and is passionate about it, so she makes the experience interesting. It's almost fun just watching her teach. The weekly response papers can be difficult, but the grading on those depends on your TA. Jackson herself is great, though. I would definitely recommend her.
She's amazing! Her comments on papers really helped me to improve my writing and find greater meaning in the text.

Thought Jackson was great. She has a fresh perspective on am. history and exposes viewpoints that most teachers wouldnt dare illuminate. Yes there are annoying parts like the section on how to write a good paper, but the focus of the class is not on fact regurgitation but critical thinking, analysis, & questioning what you think you know. Awesome.
No Comments
No Comments

sucks not only as a prof,but as a person as well.my 2nd exam i got a 77 on, went to talk to my ta who told me that "i had every fact on there (essay & IDs), which is why i got *half credit?*" they pull the grades out of their youknowwhats. if you want to learn, try someone else--shes mean, stupid, egotistical, angry, and should not be teaching.
No.  Just no.  Do yourself a favor and take this class with someone else.  (The first day of class she explained how Ronald Reagan was similar to Tim McVeigh)

she's pretty much full of bs, and if you don't agree with her, you. are. wrong.  she assigns readings and papers and talks AT you like its the only class youre taking (what?? you havent done the paper due in a week?! you=bad, baaad person) i dont know what we're doin in this class, and i dont know why i show up every day...

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Lisa is very very cool, and her class was really interesting. She put everything in a new perspective, and made me really interested in Global Studies. Her powerpoints don't make sense unless you go to class and hear her oral lecture, and discussion sections are mandatory. There are response writings, but they're not that bad. 9/10

Professor Lindsay is extremely enthusiastic about the subject, which makes it much easier to be engaged as well.  Teaching style is very chaotic though, which stressed me out sometimes, but it ended up not mattering as long as you paid attention because tests deal with broad themes, not really specifics.  Easy to get an A.  TAs are easy graders.

She's really into African history and knows what she's talking about. You don't have to read (except for discussion sections)... don't bother getting the textbook- just pay attention in class. I normally don't like history but she makes it easy to connect with

Dr. Lindsay is so smart and interesting. Her lectures could get kind of disorganized but she was always able to tie everything together. I'm not a fan of history but her class was engaging enough and is graded very fairly. Would recommend her to anyone!

Professor Lindsay is so intelligent but sometimes I felt like her lectures were kind of sporadic and not well organized. She eventually got her point across but she often rambled to get there. For that reason, you have to pay attention the entire time, or else you'll miss her point. She's super nice and easy-going though, so overall she was good!

Dr. Lindsay is a genuinely nice person, knowledgable, enthusiastic, and helpful. Most assignments in HIST278 required writing, but I personally enjoyed that. You still have to make effort to get an A, but I think it would definitely be possible to make an A without being extremely difficult. (you NEED to buy Atlantic Slave Trade by Northrup)
Great lecturer, very engaging, always offers help to students if needed.

I loved the class! I wish I had a chance to take more of Professor Lindsay's classes. She was obviously passionate about the course and it was a fairly easy course. It has been one of my favorite courses at UNC and I definitely learned a great deal. I highly recommend the course!
Dr. Lindsay is great.  Lectures are really interesting and is very passionate about the material.  Take her class
Excellent lecturer, although she gets into overdrive.  Voice takes a little getting used to.  She won't use the microphone so she gets a little screechy.
Very friendly and excited to teach the class. Interesting subject and lectures were actually a good use of time. The recitations, depending on the TA, can be the downside.

nice professor. probably easier than her ta's. she wants you to get the general ideas and themes. seems passionate about the subject, but can come across boring at times. workload is reasonable and reading is light. one of the texts is a book she wrote-easy reading. i recommend the class! good considering it's history.

I graduated and can honestly say that Professor Lindsay was the best professor I had at UNC, period!  She is so enthusiastic about teaching, so passionate about her material, so caring about her students!  She is dazzling in her lecture and her eyes really do sparkle!  I feel really fortunate to have had her.  I would love to repeat it!

Pleasing, smart, and pleasant, but at the end of the day, not that much soul or fire.  No way not to like her lectures, but unlike some of the students who have ratd her I found myself wondering whether this is just a job for her.  Sort of flat somehow.

Prof Lindsay is a fantastic lecturer--engaging, motivational, and clear--and she makes me want to know what she knows.  Excellent grasp of subject and ability to convey it.  It doesn't hurt that she is really pretty, either, but it seems there is consensus there.
Professor Lindsay is a joy to learn from! She's extremely enthusiastic about the topic and does a great job teaching it. The class itself is pretty easy. Definitely take it if you want an easy A!

Dr. Lindsay is the BEST professor I have had at UNC!  She is clear yet sophisticated, down-to-earth yet insightful.  She is witty with her words and yet brilliant in her interpretations.  She also knows how to make material accessible for students, and her passion for the material is quite inspiring.  What a gem!

Professor Lindsay is graceful and sweet, and smart as all hell.  Just when you start to think she's so charming, she dazzles you with this brainiac display.  And just when you're thinking she's a brain, she does something adorable.  I love this class.
No Comments

She really cares about her students. She recognizes that everyone in the class brings something unique to the class and that all opinions are worth hearing. Her enthusiasm for the subject is contagious, and even though I wasn't too excited about taking the class at first, it wound up being one of my favorites at Carolina!
